Comments: The date is divergent from other Eastern Amazonian Tupiguarani, but not from other Tupiguarani dates in the Xingu-Tocantins interfluve.
FullReference: Almeida, Fernando O. 2008. “O Complexo Tupi Da Amazônia Oriental.” São Paulo: University of São Paulo.
Name: Bela Vista

Comments: Not included in Bonomo et al. (2015). The style is not considered specifically Guarani, but the site is nevertheless Tupiguarani.
FullReference: Kashimoto, Emilia M, and Gilson R Martins. 2008. “A Problemática Arqueológica Da Tradição Cerâmica Tupiguarani No Mato Grosso Do Sul.” In Os Ceramistas Tupiguarani, edited by André Prous and Tania A Lima, 149–78. Belo Horizonte: Sigma.
Name: Alto Paraná 14 (MS-PR-42)

FullReference: Robrahn-González, Erika M, and Paulo Zanettini. 2001. “Programa Arqueológico de Resgate - Complexo Ecoturístico Costa de São João - Bahia - Relatório Final.” São Paulo.
Name: Sauípe 8

Comments: The date is usually accepted, but it was considered too early when originally published.
FullReference: Brochado, José Joaquim Justiniano Proenza. 1984. “An Ecological Model of the Spread of Pottery and Agriculture into Eastern South America.” Urbana-Champaign: University of Illinois.
Name: Emilio Kieffer (RS-MJ-88)

SiteDescription: Dark layer of hearths and charcoal with funerary urns buried in pits, accompanied by painted ceramics and surrounded by hearths.
FullReference: Scheel-Ybert, Rita, Kita Macario, Angela Buarque, Roberto M Anjos, and Mariana Beauclair. 2008. “A New Age to an Old Site: The Earliest Tupiguarani Settlement in Rio de Janeiro State?” Anais Da Academia Brasileira de Ciências 80: 763–70.
Name: Morro Grande (RJ00361)

FullReference: Pontim, Rute L. 2011. “A Tradição Tupiguarani Na Bacia Do Alto Tocantins.” São Paulo: University of São Paulo.
Name: Abrigo Pedra Talhada (GO-NI-176)
